notes: Cases must be de-identified before import (remove names, MRNs, exact dates, locations).
Attach PDF wave analysis as a resource reference; extract structured fields for app use.

history.eventDescription: string

eegSummary.background: string
eegSummary.epileptiform: string

taskFlow.prompt: string
taskFlow.explanation: string

starterCases.title: Childhood Absence Epilepsy - Typical Presentation
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Brief staring spells and unresponsiveness multiple times per day

history.eventDescription: Patient experiences brief episodes of staring and unresponsiveness, lasting 5-10 seconds, occurring multiple times daily. Events are abrupt in onset and offset.
history.lastEventTiming: Most recent event occurred earlier today

eegSummary.background: Normal background for age
eegSummary.epileptiform: Generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges, frontally predominant

taskFlow.prompt: Which activation procedure is most likely to increase yield for this patient?
taskFlow.explanation: Hyperventilation commonly provokes generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave in typical absence epilepsy, making it the most appropriate activation procedure for this case.

taskFlow.prompt: The EEG shows generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges. What is the most likely diagnosis?
taskFlow.explanation: Generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave is the classic pattern for typical absence epilepsy (childhood absence epilepsy), especially when provoked by hyperventilation.

starterCases.title: Infantile Spasms with Hypsarrhythmia
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Clusters of flexor spasms on awakening and developmental regression

history.eventDescription: 5-month-old infant presents with clusters of flexor spasms occurring on awakening. Parents report developmental regression over the past month.

eegSummary.background: Chaotic, high-amplitude slow waves with multifocal spikes
eegSummary.epileptiform: Multifocal spikes and sharp waves in chaotic background

taskFlow.prompt: The EEG shows a chaotic, high-amplitude pattern with multifocal spikes. What is this pattern called?
taskFlow.explanation: Hypsarrhythmia is characterized by chaotic, high-amplitude slow waves with multifocal spikes, typically seen in infantile spasms (West syndrome).

starterCases.title: Normal EEG with Benign Variants
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Normal clinical exam referred for evaluation of possible epilepsy; no spells reported

history.eventDescription: Patient referred for routine EEG evaluation. No clinical events or spells reported. Normal neurological examination.

eegSummary.background: Normal background for age
eegSummary.epileptiform: None
eegSummary.focalFindings: Benign variants: mu rhythm (central), wicket spikes (temporal)

taskFlow.prompt: The EEG shows arch-like waveforms over central regions that block with movement. What is this pattern?
taskFlow.explanation: Mu rhythm is a normal variant characterized by arch-like waveforms over central regions that block with movement or intention to move. It is not epileptiform.

starterCases.title: School-age child with GTC seizures and occipital sharp waves
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Recent onset generalized tonic-clonic convulsions associated with headaches. EEG requested to assess for epileptiform activity.

history.eventDescription: School-age child with recent onset generalized tonic-clonic convulsions associated with headaches. EEG ordered to assess for epileptiform activity.

eegSummary.background: Well-organized background, medium amplitude
eegSummary.epileptiform: Focal sharp waves in brief bursts, occipital, bilateral with left predominance, present in wake and sleep
eegSummary.focalFindings: Focal interictal epileptiform discharges in occipital regions bilaterally with left predominance

taskFlow.prompt: Which features in the history increase suspicion for epilepsy vs provoked seizure?
options: Recent onset recurrent convulsions with headache
Single brief fainting spell after dehydration
Isolated migraine aura without loss of consciousness
taskFlow.explanation: Recurrent GTC-type convulsions justify EEG assessment for epileptiform activity.

taskFlow.prompt: Which setting change is MOST likely to distort slow-wave activity and make diffuse slowing harder to appreciate?
options: Raising the low-frequency filter too high
taskFlow.explanation: Raising LFF attenuates slow activity and can mask diffuse slowing.

taskFlow.prompt: Based on the report description, what is the BEST classification of the abnormality?
options: Focal occipital interictal sharp waves (left predominant)
taskFlow.explanation: Described as brief bursts of sharp-wave activity maximal over occipital regions, bilateral but left predominant.

taskFlow.prompt: Which next step is MOST appropriate based on focal occipital epileptiform discharges in a child?
options: No further evaluation is needed if photic is normal
Brain MRI to evaluate occipital structural lesions
taskFlow.explanation: Focal epileptiform discharges often warrant structural evaluation, especially with new onset seizures.

starterCases.title: Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy - Myoclonus on Awakening
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Morning myoclonic jerks and occasional generalized tonic-clonic seizures upon awakening

history.eventDescription: 16-year-old patient reports bilateral myoclonic jerks in the morning, especially after sleep deprivation. Has had 3 generalized tonic-clonic seizures, all occurring within 30 minutes of awakening. Events are worse with sleep deprivation and alcohol consumption.
history.lastEventTiming: Most recent GTC seizure occurred 2 weeks ago after a late night

eegSummary.background: Normal background for age
eegSummary.epileptiform: Generalized polyspike-and-wave discharges, frontally predominant, activated by sleep deprivation and awakening

activations.sleep: Sleep deprivation performed, recording upon awakening

taskFlow.prompt: Which activation procedure is most effective for this patient's syndrome?
options: Sleep deprivation with recording upon awakening
taskFlow.explanation: Sleep deprivation with recording upon awakening is the most effective activation procedure for JME (90-95% yield). Myoclonic jerks and seizures typically occur upon awakening.

taskFlow.prompt: The EEG shows generalized polyspike-and-wave discharges. What is the most likely diagnosis?
taskFlow.explanation: Generalized polyspike-and-wave is characteristic of JME, especially when combined with myoclonic jerks upon awakening and GTC seizures. Polyspike-and-wave is more common in JME than pure 3 Hz spike-and-wave.

starterCases.title: Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome - Multiple Seizure Types
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Multiple seizure types including drop attacks, atypical absence, and generalized tonic-clonic seizures with developmental delay

history.eventDescription: 5-year-old child with history of multiple seizure types: atonic seizures (drop attacks), atypical absence seizures, and generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Significant developmental delay and cognitive impairment. Seizures are frequent and difficult to control.

eegSummary.background: Abnormal background with slow spike-and-wave
eegSummary.epileptiform: Slow spike-and-wave (1.5-2.5 Hz), generalized paroxysmal fast activity (GPFA) during sleep
eegSummary.focalFindings: Generalized slow spike-and-wave, GPFA during sleep

activations.sleep: Recorded - GPFA most prominent during sleep

taskFlow.prompt: The EEG shows slow spike-and-wave (1.5-2.5 Hz) and GPFA during sleep. What is the most likely diagnosis?
taskFlow.explanation: Slow spike-and-wave (1.5-2.5 Hz) and GPFA during sleep are characteristic of LGS. The triad of multiple seizure types, slow spike-and-wave, and cognitive impairment is diagnostic of LGS.

taskFlow.prompt: Which recording strategy is MOST critical for this patient?
taskFlow.explanation: Sleep recording is CRITICAL for LGS - slow spike-and-wave and GPFA are most prominent during sleep (95-100% yield). GPFA is highly characteristic of LGS and is best seen during sleep.

starterCases.title: Benign Rolandic Epilepsy - Centrotemporal Spikes
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Nocturnal facial twitching and speech arrest, normal development

history.eventDescription: 8-year-old child with episodes of facial twitching and speech arrest occurring during sleep. Events are brief and do not cause significant disruption. Normal neurological examination and development. No daytime events reported.

eegSummary.background: Normal background for age
eegSummary.epileptiform: Centrotemporal spikes (C3, C4, T3, T4), dramatically activated by sleep (10-100x increase)
eegSummary.focalFindings: Centrotemporal spikes, high amplitude, diphasic, activated by sleep

taskFlow.prompt: Which recording strategy is MOST critical for this patient?
taskFlow.explanation: Sleep recording is CRITICAL for BRE - centrotemporal spikes are dramatically activated by sleep (10-100x increase). Spikes may be rare or absent during wakefulness but become frequent during sleep.

taskFlow.prompt: The EEG shows centrotemporal spikes dramatically activated by sleep. What is the most likely diagnosis?
taskFlow.explanation: Centrotemporal spikes dramatically activated by sleep, combined with normal development and nocturnal facial twitching/speech arrest, is characteristic of Benign Rolandic Epilepsy (BRE). BRE has excellent prognosis and remits by adolescence.

starterCases.title: Dravet Syndrome - Febrile Seizures and Photosensitivity
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Recurrent febrile seizures in first year of life, now with myoclonic seizures and developmental delay

history.eventDescription: 8-month-old infant with history of febrile seizures beginning at 6 months. Now developing myoclonic seizures and showing signs of developmental delay. Seizures triggered by fever, hot baths, and photic stimulation. Status epilepticus occurred once.

eegSummary.background: Early: may be normal. Later: generalized spike-and-wave, polyspike-and-wave, multifocal spikes
eegSummary.epileptiform: Generalized spike-and-wave, polyspike-and-wave, photosensitive (pattern triggered by photic stimulation)

activations.photic: Performed - photosensitive (pattern triggered by photic stimulation, 60-80% yield)

taskFlow.prompt: Which feature is MOST characteristic of Dravet syndrome?
options: Febrile seizures in first year of life (peak 6 months)
taskFlow.explanation: Dravet syndrome begins with febrile seizures in first year of life (peak 6 months) - this is the most characteristic early feature. The syndrome is also photosensitive and fever-sensitive.

taskFlow.prompt: Which activation procedure is most effective for this patient?
taskFlow.explanation: Dravet is photosensitive - photic stimulation may trigger seizures or EEG abnormalities (60-80% yield). Photic stimulation is the most effective activation procedure for Dravet.

starterCases.title: ESES/CSWS - Cognitive Regression
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Cognitive regression and behavioral problems, infrequent seizures

history.eventDescription: 6-year-old child with recent cognitive regression and behavioral problems (hyperactivity, attention deficits). Seizures are infrequent. Parents report decline in school performance and language skills over past 6 months.

eegSummary.background: Awake: may show focal or multifocal spikes. Sleep: continuous spike-and-wave during slow-wave sleep (≥85% of NREM sleep)
eegSummary.epileptiform: Continuous spike-and-wave during slow-wave sleep (≥85% of NREM sleep). Pattern disappears in REM sleep and wakefulness.
eegSummary.focalFindings: Generalized or bilateral, maximal in centrotemporal or frontocentral regions during sleep

activations.sleep: Recorded - ESES pattern ONLY in NREM sleep (≥85% of slow-wave sleep), disappears in REM and wake

taskFlow.prompt: Which recording strategy is MOST critical for this patient?
options: Sleep recording with full sleep cycle (NREM and REM) - CRITICAL
taskFlow.explanation: Sleep recording with full sleep cycle (NREM and REM) is CRITICAL for ESES/CSWS - the ESES pattern is ONLY seen during NREM sleep (≥85% of slow-wave sleep) and disappears in REM sleep and wakefulness. This is the defining feature.

taskFlow.prompt: The EEG shows continuous spike-and-wave during NREM sleep (≥85% of slow-wave sleep) that disappears in REM and wake. What is this pattern?
taskFlow.explanation: ESES/CSWS is characterized by continuous spike-and-wave during slow-wave sleep (≥85% of NREM sleep) that disappears in REM sleep and wakefulness. Cognitive regression is the most characteristic clinical feature.

starterCases.title: Jeavons Syndrome - Eyelid Myoclonus with Eye Closure
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Rhythmic eyelid jerking with eye closure and brief staring spells

history.eventDescription: 7-year-old child with rhythmic eyelid jerking (eyelid myoclonus) that occurs with eye closure. Brief staring spells (3-6 seconds) also occur. Events are triggered by eye closure, photic stimulation, and bright lights. Normal development.

eegSummary.background: Normal background for age
eegSummary.epileptiform: Generalized 3-4 Hz spike-and-wave or polyspike-and-wave, triggered by eye closure and photic stimulation

activations.photic: Highly photosensitive (90-95% yield) - eye closure during IPS may trigger events

taskFlow.prompt: Which activation procedures are MOST critical for this patient?
options: Photic stimulation and eye closure testing (CRITICAL)
taskFlow.explanation: Photic stimulation and eye closure testing are CRITICAL for Jeavons - the syndrome is highly photosensitive (90-95% yield) and eye closure triggers events. Eye closure during photic stimulation may enhance response.

taskFlow.prompt: The EEG shows eyelid myoclonus with eye closure and generalized spike-and-wave triggered by photic stimulation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
taskFlow.explanation: Eyelid myoclonus with eye closure, combined with highly photosensitive generalized spike-and-wave, is characteristic of Jeavons Syndrome (Absence with Eyelid Myoclonus). Eye closure triggers events and photic stimulation is highly effective (90-95% yield).

starterCases.title: Frontal Lobe Epilepsy - Brief Nocturnal Seizures
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Brief nocturnal seizures with hypermotor behavior and vocalizations

history.eventDescription: 25-year-old adult with brief nocturnal seizures characterized by hypermotor behavior, vocalizations, and bilateral movements. Seizures are very brief (seconds to <1 minute) and occur during sleep. Normal daytime function.
history.lastEventTiming: Events occur during sleep, multiple times per month

eegSummary.background: Normal background for age
eegSummary.epileptiform: Frontal spikes/sharp waves, activated by sleep. Ictal: Focal onset in frontal region, may show fast activity (beta/gamma) or rhythmic patterns
eegSummary.focalFindings: Frontal spikes/sharp waves (F3, F4, Fz, F7, F8), activated by sleep

activations.sleep: Recorded - frontal spikes activated by sleep (70-80% yield)

taskFlow.prompt: The EEG shows frontal spikes activated by sleep, with brief nocturnal seizures showing hypermotor behavior. What is the most likely diagnosis?
taskFlow.explanation: Frontal spikes activated by sleep, combined with brief nocturnal seizures showing hypermotor behavior and vocalizations, is characteristic of Frontal Lobe Epilepsy. FLE seizures are often brief and may show fast activity (beta/gamma).

taskFlow.prompt: Which recording strategy is most effective for this patient?
taskFlow.explanation: Sleep recording is effective for FLE (70-80% yield) - frontal spikes are activated by sleep. Sleep deprivation may also increase yield. Ictal recording during sleep is critical for capturing seizures.

starterCases.title: Doose Syndrome (MAE) - Myoclonic-Astatic Seizures
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Myoclonic jerks followed by drop attacks and atypical absence seizures

history.eventDescription: 3-year-old child with myoclonic-astatic seizures (myoclonic jerk immediately followed by atonic drop - drop attacks). Also has atypical absence seizures. Normal neurological exam initially. Variable course - may remit or evolve to LGS.

eegSummary.background: Normal or mildly abnormal background
eegSummary.epileptiform: Generalized spike-and-wave or polyspike-and-wave (2-4 Hz) during myoclonic-astatic seizures

taskFlow.prompt: The EEG shows myoclonic-astatic seizures (myoclonic jerk followed by atonic drop). What is the most likely diagnosis?
taskFlow.explanation: Myoclonic-astatic seizures (myoclonic jerk immediately followed by atonic drop) are characteristic of Doose Syndrome (MAE). The syndrome has variable prognosis - may remit by age 5-10 years or evolve to LGS.

taskFlow.prompt: Which medication should be AVOIDED in this syndrome?
options: Carbamazepine (may worsen seizures - AED-induced seizure worsening)
taskFlow.explanation: Carbamazepine should be AVOIDED in Doose Syndrome - it may worsen seizures (AED-induced seizure worsening). Valproate, lamotrigine, and ethosuximide are preferred treatments.

starterCases.title: Ohtahara Syndrome - Burst-Suppression with Tonic Seizures
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Burst-suppression pattern with frequent tonic seizures in first weeks of life

history.eventDescription: 2-week-old neonate with burst-suppression pattern on EEG and frequent tonic seizures. Onset in first few days of life. Severe developmental delay. Pattern is continuous (present in both wake and sleep).

eegSummary.background: Burst-suppression pattern - alternating bursts of high-amplitude activity and suppression
eegSummary.epileptiform: Burst-suppression pattern, continuous (wake and sleep). Tonic seizures show bursts or electrodecremental pattern.

taskFlow.prompt: The EEG shows burst-suppression pattern that is continuous (present in both wake and sleep) with tonic seizures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
taskFlow.explanation: Burst-suppression pattern that is continuous (present in both wake and sleep) with tonic seizures is characteristic of Ohtahara Syndrome. This distinguishes it from normal neonatal trace alternant (sleep only) and EME (myoclonic seizures, not tonic).

taskFlow.prompt: Which recording strategy is critical for this patient?
options: Both awake and sleep recording (burst-suppression is continuous)
taskFlow.explanation: Both awake and sleep recording are critical - the burst-suppression pattern is continuous (present in both wake and sleep), distinguishing it from normal neonatal trace alternant (sleep only). This is a key diagnostic feature.

starterCases.title: Benign Myoclonic Epilepsy of Infancy (BMEI)
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Brief myoclonic jerks, normal development

history.eventDescription: 18-month-old infant with brief myoclonic jerks (1-3 seconds) occurring during wakefulness. No GTC seizures, no absence seizures. Normal neurological examination and normal development. Events are infrequent.

eegSummary.background: Normal background (characteristic)
eegSummary.epileptiform: Generalized spike-and-wave or polyspike-and-wave during myoclonic jerks. Normal background (distinguishes from Dravet).

taskFlow.prompt: The EEG shows myoclonic seizures only with normal background and normal development. What is the most likely diagnosis?
taskFlow.explanation: Myoclonic seizures only with normal background and normal development is characteristic of BMEI. This distinguishes it from Dravet (abnormal background, developmental delay, multiple seizure types) and JME (later onset, GTC seizures). BMEI has excellent prognosis and remits by age 3-5 years.

taskFlow.prompt: What is the prognosis for this syndrome?
options: Excellent - remits by age 3-5 years, normal development
Variable - may remit or evolve to LGS
taskFlow.explanation: BMEI has excellent prognosis - remits by age 3-5 years with normal development and no cognitive impairment. This is a benign condition, distinguishing it from severe myoclonic epilepsies like Dravet.

learningLinks.label: Syndrome: Benign Myoclonic Epilepsy of Infancy

starterCases.title: Landau-Kleffner Syndrome - Acquired Aphasia
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Acquired language loss (aphasia) and infrequent seizures

history.eventDescription: 5-year-old child with acquired aphasia (language loss) - previously normal language development. Verbal auditory agnosia (inability to understand spoken language) and expressive language loss. Seizures are infrequent or absent (paradoxical - seizures rare but EEG shows ESES). Behavioral problems also present.

eegSummary.background: Awake: may show focal or multifocal spikes (often temporal or perisylvian). Sleep: ESES pattern - continuous spike-and-wave during slow-wave sleep (≥85% of NREM sleep)
eegSummary.epileptiform: ESES pattern - continuous spike-and-wave during slow-wave sleep (≥85% of NREM sleep), often maximal in temporal or perisylvian regions. Pattern disappears in REM sleep and wakefulness.

activations.sleep: Recorded - ESES pattern ONLY in NREM sleep (≥85% of slow-wave sleep), disappears in REM and wake

taskFlow.prompt: The EEG shows ESES pattern (continuous spike-and-wave during NREM sleep) with acquired aphasia (language loss). What is the most likely diagnosis?
taskFlow.explanation: ESES pattern + ACQUIRED APHASIA (language loss) is the defining feature of Landau-Kleffner Syndrome. The acquired aphasia distinguishes LKS from other ESES cases. Paradoxical: seizures may be infrequent or absent, but EEG shows continuous spike-and-wave during sleep.

taskFlow.prompt: Which recording strategy is MOST critical for this patient?
options: Sleep recording with full sleep cycle (NREM and REM) - CRITICAL
taskFlow.explanation: Sleep recording with full sleep cycle (NREM and REM) is CRITICAL - ESES pattern is ONLY seen during NREM sleep (≥85% of slow-wave sleep) and disappears in REM sleep and wakefulness. Must record full sleep cycle to see this pattern.

starterCases.title: HIPAA Violation: Unauthorized Discussion
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Routine EEG for evaluation of possible seizures

history.eventDescription: Patient reports episodes of staring and confusion

eegSummary.background: Normal posterior dominant rhythm at 10 Hz, reactive
eegSummary.epileptiform: No epileptiform discharges
eegSummary.activation: Hyperventilation and photic stimulation performed, no activation

taskFlow.title: Identify the Ethical Issue
taskFlow.description: During the EEG, the technologist discusses the patient's case with a colleague in the hallway where other patients and visitors can overhear. The discussion includes the patient's name, symptoms, and preliminary findings.
taskFlow.question: What ethical principle is being violated?
taskFlow.explanation: HIPAA requires patient information to be discussed only with authorized personnel in appropriate settings. Discussing patient information in a public hallway violates confidentiality and patient privacy.

taskFlow.title: Determine Appropriate Action
taskFlow.description: The technologist realizes the discussion was inappropriate and wants to address the situation.
taskFlow.question: What should the technologist do?
options: Ignore it since no harm was done
Document the incident, report through appropriate channels, and complete HIPAA training
Continue with the study without addressing it
taskFlow.explanation: HIPAA violations must be reported through appropriate channels. The technologist should document the incident, report it to the supervisor/privacy officer, and complete additional HIPAA training. This ensures compliance and prevents future violations.

starterCases.title: Patient Safety: Equipment Malfunction
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Routine EEG for evaluation of staring episodes

history.eventDescription: Episodes of staring and unresponsiveness

eegSummary.background: Normal age-appropriate background
eegSummary.epileptiform: No epileptiform discharges

taskFlow.title: Identify Safety Issue
taskFlow.description: During electrode application, the technologist notices a small spark when connecting an electrode cable. The cable appears intact but the spark is concerning.
taskFlow.question: What is the MOST appropriate immediate action?
options: Continue with the study if the spark was minor
Stop immediately, disconnect equipment, tag as out of service, and use backup equipment
Check if the patient was harmed first
taskFlow.explanation: Electrical safety is paramount. Any sign of electrical malfunction (sparks, damaged cables) requires immediate action: stop the study, disconnect equipment, tag as out of service, notify supervisor, and use backup equipment. Patient safety overrides diagnostic yield.

taskFlow.title: Document and Report
taskFlow.description: After ensuring patient safety and switching to backup equipment, the technologist needs to document the incident.
taskFlow.question: What should be documented?
options: The equipment malfunction, actions taken, patient safety measures, and notification of supervisor
Nothing if no patient harm occurred
taskFlow.explanation: All safety incidents must be fully documented: the malfunction, immediate actions taken, patient safety measures, equipment tagged out, backup equipment used, and supervisor notification. Complete documentation protects patients and facilities.

learningLinks.label: Domain IV: Patient Safety & Professional Standards
Domain IV: Quality Assurance & Equipment Maintenance

starterCases.title: Scope of Practice: Clinical Interpretation
starterCases.chiefComplaint: EEG for evaluation of absence seizures

history.eventDescription: Episodes of staring and unresponsiveness, triggered by hyperventilation

eegSummary.background: Normal posterior dominant rhythm at 10 Hz
eegSummary.epileptiform: Generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges, activated by hyperventilation
eegSummary.activation: Hyperventilation activated generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges

taskFlow.title: Identify Scope of Practice Violation
taskFlow.description: The technologist writes in the technical report: 'This EEG is consistent with childhood absence epilepsy. The patient has absence seizures.'
taskFlow.question: What is wrong with this documentation?
options: Technologists should describe patterns objectively, not diagnose conditions
taskFlow.explanation: Technologists document objective observations using standardized terminology. They describe patterns (e.g., 'generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges') but do NOT diagnose conditions (e.g., 'childhood absence epilepsy'). Scope of practice: observe and document, do not interpret clinically.

taskFlow.title: Correct Documentation
taskFlow.description: The technologist needs to rewrite the report using appropriate terminology.
taskFlow.question: What is the CORRECT way to document these findings?
options: "Generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges, activated by hyperventilation. No focal findings."
"The patient has absence epilepsy with 3 Hz spike-and-wave"
taskFlow.explanation: Correct documentation uses objective, standardized terminology to describe observable patterns: 'Generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges, activated by hyperventilation. No focal findings.' Avoid clinical diagnoses, interpretations, or conclusions.

learningLinks.label: Domain IV: EEG Documentation & Reporting Standards

starterCases.title: Emergency Response: Status Epilepticus
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Continuous EEG monitoring in ICU

history.eventDescription: Patient admitted with altered mental status, continuous EEG ordered

eegSummary.background: Diffuse slowing, 4-6 Hz theta range
eegSummary.epileptiform: Generalized periodic discharges

taskFlow.title: Recognize Emergency
taskFlow.description: During continuous EEG monitoring, the technologist observes on the EEG screen a pattern that suggests nonconvulsive status epilepticus. The patient appears unresponsive but is not convulsing.
taskFlow.question: What is the FIRST priority?
options: Continue monitoring to confirm the pattern
Ensure patient safety, initiate emergency response per protocol, and notify the physician immediately
Wait for the physician's routine rounds
Document it in the report only
taskFlow.explanation: Patient safety is the first priority. If nonconvulsive status epilepticus is suspected, ensure patient safety, initiate emergency response per institutional protocol, and notify the physician immediately. Do not wait - status epilepticus is a medical emergency.

taskFlow.title: Maintain Recording During Emergency
taskFlow.description: While emergency response is activated, the technologist should:
taskFlow.question: What should the technologist do with the EEG recording?
options: Stop the recording to focus on patient care
Continue recording if it can be done safely - the data is valuable for treatment
Only record if the physician requests it
taskFlow.explanation: If recording can be maintained safely during emergency response, continue recording. The EEG data during status epilepticus is valuable for treatment decisions. However, patient safety always comes first - if maintaining recording compromises safety, prioritize patient care.

learningLinks.label: Domain IV: Patient Safety & Professional Standards

starterCases.title: Quality Assurance: Calibration Failure
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Routine EEG for evaluation of headaches

history.eventDescription: Recurrent headaches, EEG ordered to rule out seizures

eegSummary.background: Normal posterior dominant rhythm at 9 Hz
eegSummary.epileptiform: No epileptiform discharges

taskFlow.title: Identify Calibration Issue
taskFlow.description: Before starting the study, the technologist performs routine calibration check and notices that the calibration signal amplitude is inconsistent across channels - some channels show 50 μV, others show 45 μV or 55 μV when they should all show 50 μV.
taskFlow.question: What should the technologist do?
options: Proceed with the study and note the calibration issue in the report
Tag equipment as out of service, notify supervisor, and use backup equipment
Ignore if the difference is small
taskFlow.explanation: Calibration inconsistencies indicate equipment malfunction and affect signal accuracy. Equipment with calibration problems must be taken out of service immediately, supervisor notified, and backup equipment used. Never use malfunctioning equipment or attempt to compensate with settings.

taskFlow.title: Document Equipment Issue
taskFlow.description: After switching to backup equipment and completing the study, the technologist needs to document the equipment issue.
taskFlow.question: What should be documented?
options: Only that backup equipment was used
The calibration failure, equipment tagged out, backup equipment used, supervisor notification, and study completion
Nothing if the study was completed successfully
Only if the patient asks about it
taskFlow.explanation: All equipment issues must be fully documented: the calibration failure, equipment tagged out of service, backup equipment used, supervisor notification, and successful study completion. This ensures quality assurance, equipment maintenance tracking, and regulatory compliance.

learningLinks.label: Domain IV: Quality Assurance & Equipment Maintenance

starterCases.title: High Impedance Troubleshooting - Multiple Electrodes
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Routine EEG for evaluation of headaches

history.eventDescription: Patient reports frequent headaches over past 3 months

eegSummary.background: Unable to assess due to artifacts
eegSummary.epileptiform: Unable to assess
eegSummary.artifacts: High impedance artifacts in multiple electrodes

taskFlow.title: Identify High Impedance Problem
taskFlow.description: After applying electrodes, the technologist checks impedance and finds that 8 electrodes (Fp1, Fp2, F3, F4, C3, C4, P3, P4) show impedance >10 kΩ, while other electrodes are <2 kΩ.
taskFlow.question: What should the technologist do?
options: Proceed with recording and document high impedance
Re-prepare all affected electrodes systematically (clean, abrade, reapply paste/gel)
Use different montage to avoid affected electrodes
taskFlow.explanation: High impedance in multiple electrodes requires systematic re-preparation: clean skin thoroughly, abrade if necessary, reapply paste/gel. Do not compensate with settings - fix the source. High impedance causes artifacts, noise, and reduced signal quality.

taskFlow.title: Verify Impedance Resolution
taskFlow.description: After re-preparing electrodes, the technologist re-checks impedance and finds all electrodes are now <3 kΩ and balanced.
taskFlow.question: What should the technologist do next?
options: Verify impedance is stable, then start recording
taskFlow.explanation: After re-preparation, verify impedance is low (<5 kΩ, ideally <2 kΩ) and balanced before starting recording. Stable, low impedance ensures optimal signal quality. <3 kΩ is acceptable for routine EEG.

starterCases.title: Montage Selection - Phase Reversal Localization
starterCases.chiefComplaint: EEG for evaluation of possible seizures

history.eventDescription: Patient reports episodes of staring and unresponsiveness

eegSummary.background: Normal posterior dominant rhythm at 10 Hz
eegSummary.epileptiform: Focal spikes in left temporal region
eegSummary.focalFindings: Left temporal spikes with phase reversal at T3

taskFlow.title: Initial Montage Observation
taskFlow.description: In referential montage (A1+A2 linked ears), the technologist observes sharp waves appearing in T3 channel. The activity appears equal in amplitude in T3 compared to surrounding channels.
taskFlow.question: What should the technologist do next?
options: Document focal activity at T3 based on referential montage only
Switch to bipolar montage to confirm localization with phase reversal
taskFlow.explanation: Referential montage shows the field of activity but doesn't confirm localization. Bipolar montage with phase reversal confirms the exact electrode location. Always compare montages for accurate localization.

taskFlow.title: Phase Reversal Confirmation
taskFlow.description: In bipolar longitudinal montage (Fp1-F7, F7-T3, T3-T5, T5-O1), the technologist observes clear phase reversal at T3 - the spike appears negative in F7-T3 and positive in T3-T5.
taskFlow.question: What does this phase reversal indicate?
options: Focal activity localized at T3 electrode (left mid-temporal)
taskFlow.explanation: Phase reversal in bipolar montage indicates the electrode where the activity is localized. Negative in F7-T3 and positive in T3-T5 means the activity is at T3 (the common electrode). This confirms focal left temporal localization.

learningLinks.label: Domain II: Montages & Strategy During Recording

starterCases.title: Activation Procedures - Hyperventilation Response
starterCases.chiefComplaint: EEG for evaluation of absence seizures

history.eventDescription: Teacher reports episodes of staring and unresponsiveness lasting 10-15 seconds

eegSummary.background: Normal posterior dominant rhythm at 9 Hz
eegSummary.epileptiform: Generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave during hyperventilation

taskFlow.title: Hyperventilation Technique
taskFlow.description: The technologist begins hyperventilation activation. The patient is instructed to breathe deeply and regularly.
taskFlow.question: What is the appropriate hyperventilation technique?
options: Deep, regular breathing at 20-30 breaths per minute for 3-5 minutes or until activation occurs
As fast as possible for 2 minutes
taskFlow.explanation: Hyperventilation should be deep, regular breathing at 20-30 breaths per minute for 3-5 minutes or until activation occurs. This creates hypocapnia (low CO2) and cerebral vasoconstriction, which can activate epileptiform discharges, particularly in absence epilepsy.

taskFlow.title: Hyperventilation Response
taskFlow.description: After 2 minutes of hyperventilation, the technologist observes generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges on the EEG, correlating with clinical staring episodes.
taskFlow.question: What should the technologist do?
options: Continue hyperventilation for full 5 minutes regardless
Continue hyperventilation for a few more seconds to document the pattern, then stop and allow patient to recover
taskFlow.explanation: When activation occurs, continue for a few more seconds to document the pattern, then stop hyperventilation and allow patient to recover. Document the response, timing, and clinical correlation. The build-up will gradually resolve over 1-2 minutes as CO2 returns to normal.

starterCases.title: Artifact Troubleshooting - 60 Hz Line Noise
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Routine EEG for evaluation

history.eventDescription: Routine evaluation

eegSummary.background: Obscured by 60 Hz artifact
eegSummary.epileptiform: Unable to assess
eegSummary.artifacts: 60 Hz line noise in all channels

taskFlow.title: Identify 60 Hz Artifact
taskFlow.description: The technologist notices regular 60 Hz sinusoidal activity in all channels, obscuring the underlying EEG.
taskFlow.question: What is the most likely cause?
options: Electrical interference from power lines or unshielded equipment, possibly exacerbated by high electrode impedance
taskFlow.explanation: 60 Hz line noise is caused by electrical interference from power lines or unshielded equipment. High electrode impedance increases susceptibility to 60 Hz interference. This is NOT brain activity - it's environmental electrical interference.

taskFlow.title: Troubleshoot 60 Hz Artifact
taskFlow.description: The technologist needs to eliminate the 60 Hz artifact.
taskFlow.question: What should the technologist do?
options: Check grounding, verify electrode impedance is low, eliminate sources (unshielded equipment, fluorescent lights), then use notch filter only if necessary
taskFlow.explanation: Eliminate 60 Hz at the source first: check grounding, verify low impedance (<5 kΩ), eliminate sources (unshielded equipment, fluorescent lights). Notch filter is last resort as it affects signals near 60 Hz. Do not compensate with settings - fix the source.

starterCases.title: Special Protocols - ICU Continuous Monitoring
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Continuous EEG monitoring for altered mental status

history.eventDescription: Patient with altered mental status, possible nonconvulsive status epilepticus

eegSummary.background: Diffuse slowing, theta-delta range
eegSummary.epileptiform: Generalized periodic discharges (GPDs) at 1-2 Hz

taskFlow.title: Recognize Ictal Pattern
taskFlow.description: During continuous monitoring, the technologist observes rhythmic delta activity that evolves in frequency (starting at 2 Hz, increasing to 4 Hz) and amplitude (increasing over 30 seconds), with spread from frontal to generalized distribution.
taskFlow.question: What does this pattern suggest?
options: Ictal pattern (seizure activity) - evolution is characteristic of ictal patterns
taskFlow.explanation: Ictal patterns evolve in frequency, amplitude, and distribution. Evolution is a key characteristic of ictal patterns. This requires immediate notification of the medical team as it suggests ongoing seizure activity (possibly nonconvulsive status epilepticus).

taskFlow.title: Notify Medical Team
taskFlow.description: The technologist has identified an evolving ictal pattern suggesting seizure activity.
taskFlow.question: What should the technologist do?
options: Document and wait for routine review
Immediately notify the medical team (physician, nursing) of the ictal pattern
Only notify if patient has clinical symptoms
taskFlow.explanation: Ictal patterns require immediate notification of the medical team (physician, nursing). Nonconvulsive status epilepticus is a medical emergency requiring prompt treatment. Do not wait for routine review - notify immediately when ictal patterns are identified.

learningLinks.label: Domain II: Event Monitoring & Emergency Response

starterCases.title: Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Stroke - Most Common Stroke
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Acute onset right-sided weakness and speech difficulty

history.eventDescription: Patient presented with sudden onset right-sided weakness (face and arm > leg) and non-fluent speech. History of hypertension and atrial fibrillation.

eegSummary.background: Focal polymorphic delta slowing over left frontal/temporal/parietal regions (F3, T3, P3)
eegSummary.epileptiform: None
eegSummary.focalFindings: Focal slowing over left MCA territory (F3, F4, T3, T4, P3, P4) - consistent with acute MCA stroke

taskFlow.title: Recognize MCA Stroke Pattern
taskFlow.description: The EEG shows focal polymorphic delta slowing over left frontal/temporal/parietal regions (F3, T3, P3). The patient has right-sided weakness (face/arm > leg) and non-fluent speech.
taskFlow.question: What does this pattern suggest?
options: Acute left MCA stroke - focal slowing over MCA territory with contralateral face/arm weakness and aphasia
taskFlow.explanation: Focal polymorphic delta slowing over left frontal/temporal/parietal regions (F3, T3, P3) with contralateral face/arm weakness and aphasia is characteristic of acute left MCA stroke. MCA is the most common stroke type and supplies lateral frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes.

taskFlow.title: Localize the Stroke
taskFlow.description: The EEG shows focal slowing over F3, T3, P3 (left hemisphere). The patient has Broca aphasia (non-fluent speech, preserved comprehension).
taskFlow.question: Which MCA division is affected?
options: Anterior MCA (Broca area) - anterior MCA supplies Broca area in left frontal lobe
taskFlow.explanation: Broca aphasia (non-fluent speech, preserved comprehension) indicates anterior MCA stroke affecting Broca area (left frontal lobe). Posterior MCA affects Wernicke area (fluent aphasia with poor comprehension). Entire MCA causes global aphasia.

learningLinks.label: Domain I: Brain Structures & Functions - Blood Supply

starterCases.title: Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) Stroke
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Acute onset left leg weakness and urinary incontinence

history.eventDescription: Patient presented with sudden onset left leg weakness (leg > arm > face), urinary incontinence, and behavioral changes (apathy, abulia). History of hypertension.

eegSummary.background: Focal polymorphic delta slowing over medial frontal regions (Fp1, Fp2, Fz)
eegSummary.epileptiform: None
eegSummary.focalFindings: Focal slowing over medial frontal regions (Fp1, Fp2, Fz) - consistent with right ACA stroke

taskFlow.title: Recognize ACA Stroke Pattern
taskFlow.description: The EEG shows focal polymorphic delta slowing over medial frontal regions (Fp1, Fp2, Fz). The patient has left leg weakness (leg > arm > face), urinary incontinence, and behavioral changes.
taskFlow.question: What does this pattern suggest?
options: Acute right ACA stroke - focal slowing over medial frontal regions with contralateral leg weakness and urinary incontinence
taskFlow.explanation: Focal polymorphic delta slowing over medial frontal regions (Fp1, Fp2, Fz) with contralateral leg weakness (leg > arm > face), urinary incontinence, and behavioral changes is characteristic of acute ACA stroke. ACA supplies medial frontal and parietal lobes (leg motor/sensory cortex).

taskFlow.title: Distinguish ACA from MCA Stroke
taskFlow.description: The patient has leg weakness (leg > arm > face) and urinary incontinence. The EEG shows medial frontal slowing.
taskFlow.question: How does this differ from MCA stroke?
options: ACA stroke: leg > arm > face weakness, medial frontal slowing, urinary incontinence. MCA stroke: face/arm > leg weakness, lateral temporal-parietal slowing, aphasia
taskFlow.explanation: ACA stroke: leg > arm > face weakness, medial frontal slowing (Fp1, Fp2, Fz), urinary incontinence, behavioral changes. MCA stroke: face/arm > leg weakness, lateral temporal-parietal slowing (F3, F4, T3, T4, P3, P4), aphasia (if dominant hemisphere).

learningLinks.label: Domain I: Brain Structures & Functions - Blood Supply

starterCases.title: Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) Stroke
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Acute onset visual field defect

history.eventDescription: Patient presented with sudden onset left homonymous hemianopia (visual field defect). History of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

eegSummary.background: Focal slowing over right occipital regions (O2, Oz), loss of PDR (posterior dominant rhythm)
eegSummary.epileptiform: None
eegSummary.focalFindings: Focal slowing over right occipital regions (O2, Oz) with loss of PDR - consistent with right PCA stroke

taskFlow.title: Recognize PCA Stroke Pattern
taskFlow.description: The EEG shows focal slowing over right occipital regions (O2, Oz) with loss of PDR. The patient has left homonymous hemianopia.
taskFlow.question: What does this pattern suggest?
options: Acute right PCA stroke - focal slowing over occipital regions with loss of PDR and contralateral homonymous hemianopia
taskFlow.explanation: Focal slowing over occipital regions (O2, Oz) with loss of PDR and contralateral homonymous hemianopia is characteristic of acute PCA stroke. PCA supplies occipital lobe (visual cortex). Loss of PDR reflects visual cortex dysfunction.

taskFlow.title: Understand PCA Territory
taskFlow.description: The patient has left homonymous hemianopia. The EEG shows right occipital slowing and loss of PDR.
taskFlow.question: What else can PCA stroke affect?
options: Occipital lobe (visual cortex), inferior temporal lobe, thalamus (via thalamoperforating branches), and midbrain - can cause memory impairment if affects hippocampus/thalamus
taskFlow.explanation: PCA supplies occipital lobe (visual cortex), inferior temporal lobe, thalamus (via thalamoperforating branches), and midbrain. PCA stroke can cause memory impairment if it affects hippocampus/thalamus, visual hallucinations, and thalamic syndromes (sensory loss, pain).

learningLinks.label: Domain I: Brain Structures & Functions - Blood Supply

starterCases.title: Basilar Artery Stroke - Brainstem Signs
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Acute onset diplopia, dysarthria, and decreased consciousness

history.eventDescription: Patient presented with sudden onset diplopia (double vision), dysarthria (slurred speech), vertigo, ataxia, and decreased consciousness. History of hypertension and diabetes.

eegSummary.background: Diffuse slowing, theta-delta range, reduced reactivity
eegSummary.epileptiform: None
eegSummary.focalFindings: Diffuse slowing with reduced reactivity - consistent with basilar artery stroke affecting brainstem

taskFlow.title: Recognize Basilar Artery Stroke
taskFlow.description: The EEG shows diffuse slowing with reduced reactivity. The patient has diplopia, dysarthria, vertigo, ataxia, and decreased consciousness.
taskFlow.question: What does this pattern suggest?
options: Basilar artery stroke - diffuse slowing with reduced reactivity due to brainstem involvement affecting consciousness
taskFlow.explanation: Diffuse slowing with reduced reactivity and brainstem signs (diplopia, dysarthria, vertigo, ataxia, decreased consciousness) is characteristic of basilar artery stroke. Basilar artery supplies pons, brainstem nuclei, and cerebellum. Severe cases can cause locked-in syndrome.

taskFlow.title: Understand Basilar Territory
taskFlow.description: The patient has brainstem signs: diplopia, dysarthria, vertigo, ataxia, and decreased consciousness.
taskFlow.question: What does basilar artery supply?
options: Pons, brainstem nuclei, cerebellum (via AICA, SCA), and midbrain - affects consciousness, eye movements, coordination
taskFlow.explanation: Basilar artery supplies pons, brainstem nuclei, cerebellum (via AICA, SCA), and midbrain. Basilar stroke causes brainstem signs: diplopia (cranial nerve palsies), dysarthria, vertigo, ataxia, decreased consciousness. Severe cases → locked-in syndrome (quadriplegia, preserved consciousness, only vertical eye movements).

learningLinks.label: Domain I: Brain Structures & Functions - Blood Supply

starterCases.title: Lateral Medullary (Wallenberg) Syndrome - PICA Occlusion
starterCases.chiefComplaint: Acute onset vertigo, dysphagia, and hoarseness

history.eventDescription: Patient presented with sudden onset vertigo, nystagmus, dysphagia, hoarseness, ipsilateral facial pain loss, contralateral body pain/temperature loss, ipsilateral Horner syndrome, and ataxia. History of hypertension.

eegSummary.background: Mild diffuse slowing, may show abnormalities if severe
eegSummary.epileptiform: None
eegSummary.focalFindings: May show mild abnormalities, but Wallenberg syndrome primarily affects brainstem (not well-seen on scalp EEG)

taskFlow.title: Recognize Wallenberg Syndrome
taskFlow.description: The patient has vertigo, nystagmus, dysphagia, hoarseness, ipsilateral facial pain loss, contralateral body pain/temperature loss, ipsilateral Horner syndrome, and ataxia.
taskFlow.question: What does this pattern suggest?
options: Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome - PICA occlusion affecting lateral medulla
taskFlow.explanation: Wallenberg syndrome is caused by PICA occlusion (branch of vertebral artery), affecting lateral medulla. Features: vertigo, nystagmus, dysphagia, hoarseness (CN IX, X), ipsilateral facial pain loss, contralateral body pain/temperature loss, ipsilateral Horner syndrome, ataxia.

taskFlow.title: Understand PICA Territory
taskFlow.description: The patient has Wallenberg syndrome with brainstem signs.
taskFlow.question: What does PICA supply?
options: Posterior and inferior cerebellum, medulla - PICA is branch of vertebral artery
taskFlow.explanation: PICA (Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery) is a branch of vertebral artery. It supplies posterior and inferior cerebellum and medulla. Occlusion causes Wallenberg syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome).

learningLinks.label: Domain I: Brain Structures & Functions - Blood Supply
